item.description: European energy imports/exports, Ukraine border crossing sites, conspiracy theory language, ISS photo locations, and software sunsets.
item.content:encoded:
European energy imports/exports, Ukraine border crossing sites, conspiracy theory language, ISS photo locations, and software sunsets.

Â 

European energy imports/exports. The EUâ€™s Eurostat office publishes a range of statistical datasets on energy usage and economics, including annual imports and exports of petroleum, natural gas, and coal between European countries and their trading partners. Related: The Energy Information Administration tracks US imports and exports of petroleum, natural gas, and coal. As seen in: How Europe is dependent on Russian gas (New Statesman) and Why the Toughest Sanctions on Russia Are the Hardest for Europe to Wield (New York Times). Previously: European gas storage (DIP 2022.01.26), state-owned oil companies (DIP 2019.05.01), and global and gas infrastructure (DIP 2018.06.06). [h/t Lisa Charlotte Muth]

Â 

Ukraine border crossing sites. The UNâ€™s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in Ukraine has combined information from multiple sources to create a geospatial dataset of the countryâ€™s international border crossings with Moldova (11 crossings listed), Poland (8), Hungary (5), Romania (4), and Slovakia (2). It provides each crossingâ€™s latitude, longitude, border country, and name in both Ukrainian and English. The associated metadata indicates an â€œexpected update frequencyâ€ of weekly.

Â 

Conspiracy theory language. Alessandro Miani et al. have built a dataset to study the language of conspiracy theories. Starting with a set of phrases associated with major conspiracy theories (e.g., those surrounding Princess Dianaâ€™s death), the authors searched online for sources that mentioned them often, ultimately selecting 150 websites â€” both mainstream and conspiracy-laden â€” that met their criteria. Then, in mid-2020, they collected 72,000+ topical articles from those sites. For each article, the project includes its text, lexical features, and metadata. [h/t Gwern Branwen]

Â 

ISS photo locations. In 2013, Nathan Bergey crawled NASAâ€™s website of International Space Station imagery, creating a dataset that listed the mission, roll, frame, latitude, and longitude of each of the million-plus photographs ever taken from the habitable satellite. Related: NASA itself also provides tools for searching, browsing, and mapping ISS imagery. [h/t Sasha Trubetskoy]

Â 

Software sunsets. The website endoflife.date tracks â€œend of lifeâ€ dates and â€œsupport lifecyclesâ€ for roughly 100 software products â€”Â languages, frameworks, operating systems, and more. It indicates, for example, that Python 3.10 appeared in October 2021 and will lose security support in October 2026. You can access the projectâ€™s machine-readable data through its GitHub repository and API.

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.03.09 edition
item.description: Refugees fleeing Ukraine, international crises, foreign ministry statements, prison COVID policies, and medieval prices.
item.content:encoded:
Refugees fleeing Ukraine, international crises, foreign ministry statements, prison COVID policies, and medieval prices.

Â 

Refugees fleeing Ukraine. The UNâ€™s refugee agency last week launched a data portal tracking the arrival of refugees from Ukraine in other countries. The daily-updated maps, charts, and structured data provide counts and estimates of arrivals by date, by receiving country, and overall. Related: The UNâ€™s Refugee Population Statistics Database, which â€œcontains information about forcibly displaced populations spanning more than 70 years of statistical activities.â€

Â 

International crises. The International Crisis Behavior Project, initiated in 1975, collects detailed data about interstate military-security crises such as the Mukden Incident, Cuban Missile Crisis, and Russiaâ€™s 2014 invasion of Crimea. The projectâ€™s datasets and online catalog, now in their 14th version, have come to cover 487 crises between 1918 and 2017. The dozens of variables include the start and end dates, type of triggering event, centrality of violence, use of mediation, type of outcome, and more. Related: The International Crisis Behavior Events project, developed by a separate group of researchers, has translated the sub-events within ICBâ€™s summaries into structured data. [h/t Lynn Cherny]

Â 

Foreign ministry statements. The FOCUSdata project, led by New Jersey City Universityâ€™s National Security Studies Department, has compiled English-language statements and articles from the foreign ministries and state media in Russia, North Korea, China, and Iran. Many of the collections span more than a decade, and typically extend to 2019 or 2020. The project also presents interactive charts showing estimated sentiment trends and topic frequencies. [h/t Graig Klein + Juste Codjo]

Â 

Prison COVID policies. Between April 2020 and April 2021, researchers at the UCLA Law COVID Behind Bars Data Project gathered 3,500+ policy announcements from federal and state prison agencies in the US. Their Prison Policy Index spreadsheet, published earlier this year, describes the announcements they gathered through April 2021. It indicates the state, date publicized, and date collected, and provides an archival link, a short summary, and a series of columns classifying the policies announced.

Â 

Medieval prices. The Medieval and Early Modern Data Bank, an effort that dates back to the 1980s, contains six datasets relating to currency exchanges, prices, wages, and textile production in Europe â€œcirca 800-1815 C.E.â€ The records, which have been compiled from prior publications (such as a statistical compendium of grain sales in Cologne), can be queried online or downloaded in bulk. [h/t Vlad Zavidovych + Mirko Lorenz]

Â

item.content:encoded:
People affected by Trumpâ€™s travel ban, Erasmus exchanges, national climate funds, sites that support HTTPs, and board games.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ In a similar vein as last weekâ€™s link to the unofficial @DataIsPluralBot: You might also enjoy Amelia Wattenbergerâ€™s DIP-randomizing webpage, stocked with 3D gift boxes and custom illustrations.

Â 

People affected by Trumpâ€™s travel ban. On January 27, 2017, thenâ€“President Trump issued an executive order suspending entry to the United States by citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries. For a recent, year-long HuffPost investigation, reporter Rowaida Abdelaziz led a team that collected and categorized the stories of 874 people affected by the travel ban, such as those who separated from a parent or child. An anonymized spreadsheet indicates the types of loss each person experienced, their nationalities, and other relevant details. Related: Between September 2019 and January 2021, the State Department published monthly, cumulative statistics about visa applications affected by later versions of the travel ban, but only as PDF reports. [h/t David Vine]

Â 

Erasmus exchanges. The European Union publishes data on the movement of students, staff, and trainees through its Erasmus+ exchange program. The most recent dataset covers academic years 2014â€“15 through 2019â€“20, detailing the international transfer of millions of participants. Each row lists a combination of variables and the number of participants who matched that description. The variables include the field of education, participant gender and nationality, duration of the exchange, sending and receiving cities and organizations, and more. As seen in: Erasmus a dos velocidades (El Confidencial). [h/t Rose Mintzer-Sweeney]

Â 

National climate funds. Boston Universityâ€™s Rishikesh Ram Bhandary has constructed an inventory of national funds for financing action on climate change. The dataset, which you can download or browse interactively, currently covers 46 funds in 39 developing countries. It lists each fundâ€™s title, year established, source of funding, host entity, scope, and more.

Â 

Sites that support HTTPS. DuckDuckGoâ€™s Smarter Encryption project provides a big text file that lists every website that the company knows supports HTTPS, the internet encryption protocol. The list contains 31+ million entries, updated via a web crawler. Related: Last year, the Electronic Frontier Foundation began incorporating the data into its HTTPS Everywhere browser extension. (It has since announced plans to retire the decade-in-service extension, now that â€œHTTPS is truly just about everywhere.â€) [h/t Giulio Magnifico]

Â 

Board games. BoardGameGeek users have submitted millions of ratings over the past two decades, judging tens of thousands of games. The website provides an API that lets you search for games and retrieve detailed information about their attributes and ratings. As seen in: â€œDiving into BoardGameGeek,â€ by Jesse van Elteren, who crawled the API to compile a dataset of 19 million ratings from 410,000+ users. [h/t Jordan Isip]

Â

item.description: Abortion facility distances, Chinaâ€™s tech giants abroad, House committee witnesses, immigrant populations in 1900, and borrowed words.
item.content:encoded:
Abortion facility distances, Chinaâ€™s tech giants abroad, House committee witnesses, immigrant populations in 1900, and borrowed words.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Data Is Plural isnâ€™t officially on Twitter. But if you want a smÃ¶rgÃ¥sbord of past datasets in your feed, you can follow @DataIsPluralBot, recently created by DIP subscriber Oscar Baruffa.

Â 

Abortion facility distances. Caitlin Knowles Myers, an economist with a focus on reproductive policy, has compiled a dataset that calculates â€” for every county in the contiguous US, every month between January 2009 and June 2021 â€” the distance you would have to travel to the nearest abortion facility. Researchers can also request access to Myersâ€™s underlying database of the facilities themselves. As described in her working paper, â€œMeasuring the Burden: The Effect of Travel Distance on Abortions and Births,â€ Myers gathered the information from a range of sources, including state licensing databases, facility websites, and Planned Parenthood directories. As seen in: â€œAbortions could require 200-mile trips if Roe is overturnedâ€ (Axios). [h/t Rose Mintzer-Sweeney]

Â 

Chinese technology companies abroad. Mapping Chinaâ€™s Tech Giants, a project relaunched by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute last year, examines the overseas expansion of 27 major Chinese technology companies, from Alibaba to ZTE. The projectâ€™s dataset includes 3,900+ entries, each describing and locating an operation or connection abroad. Theyâ€™re grouped into a couple dozen categories, such as commercial partnerships, overseas offices, data centers, 5G relationships, training, and donations. [h/t Samantha Hoffman]

Â 

House committee witnesses. Political scientists Lauren C. Bell and J.D. Rackey have compiled a spreadsheet of 435,000+ people testifying before the US House of Representatives from 1971 to 2016. They began with a text file scraped from a ProQuest database, provided by the authors of a dataset that focused on social scientistsâ€™ testimony (DIP 2020.12.23). Then, they determined each witnessâ€™s first and last name; type of organization; the committee, date, title, and summary of the relevant hearing; and more. [h/t Derek Willis]

Â 

Immigrant populations in 1900. The 1900 US Censusâ€™s public report includes a table counting the foreign-born residents of each state and territory â€” overall and disaggregated into a few dozen origins, which range from subdivisions of countries (Poland is split into â€œAustrian,â€ â€œGerman,â€ â€œRussian,â€ and â€œunknownâ€ columns) to entire continents (â€œAfricaâ€). Itâ€™s officially available as a low-resolution PDF. Reporters at Stacker, however, recently transcribed it into a CSV file for easier use. [h/t Emilia Ruzicka]

Â 

Borrowed words. The World Loanword Database, a project from the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, examines how languages have borrowed words from each other. For 41 historical and contemporary languages, it lists 1,000â€“2,500 words, expertsâ€™ judgment of whether they were borrowed, from what language, and other etymological details. Previously: The World Atlas of Language Structures (DIP 2016.01.06). [h/t blopeur]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.01.26 edition
item.description: Redistricting, SARS-CoV-2 in local sewage, collective bargaining, European gas storage, and whaling.
item.content:encoded:
Redistricting, SARS-CoV-2 in local sewage, collective bargaining, European gas storage, and whaling.

Â 

Redistricting. US decennial redistricting is well underway, with redrawn legislative maps approved in the majority of states. FiveThirtyEight, Politico, and The Washington Post have all built graphics tracking the process and its likely effects on Congress. The Redistricting Data Hub, a project of the Fair Representation in Redistricting Initiative, has been gathering statesâ€™ proposed and approved maps (e.g., Californiaâ€™s, from its commission), as well other datasets useful for analyzing the changes. All About Redistricting, a resource founded by Loyola Law Schoolâ€™s Justin Levitt, also publishes state mapping data, as well as a downloadable table describing who controls each stateâ€™s redistricting process.

Â 

SARS-CoV-2 in local sewage. Biobot Analytics, a wastewater epidemiology company, has been partnering with local governments to monitor sewage for traces of coronavirus. Their public dashboard and downloadable data provide weekly estimates of the number of SARS-CoV-2 genome copies per milliliter of wastewater â€” at a national and regional level, and for 31 of the participating communities (some with data more recent than others). Read more: â€œIn Sewage, Clues to Omicronâ€™s Surgeâ€ (The New York Times). [h/t Dave Pell]

Â 

Collective bargaining. The US Federal Mediation and Conciliation Serviceâ€™s stated mission â€œis to preserve and promote labor-management peace and cooperation.â€ It also publishes spreadsheets of data submitted through its Form F-7, which employers and unions must file when they canâ€™t agree on modifying or ending a collectively bargained contract. The spreadsheets, which go back to 2015, list the employer and unionâ€™s name and location, their industry, the size of the bargaining unit, and a few other details. Previously: Union elections (DIP 2021.05.05) and voluntary recognition (DIP 2021.09.22). [h/t Dan Bauman]

Â 

European gas storage. The industry group Gas Infrastructure Europe publishes data on daily fuel storage levels at its membersâ€™ facilities. For each facility, and aggregated to the provider and country level, the data indicate the amount of fuel in storage, the percent capacity that represents, fuel added and withdrawn, and more. As seen in: â€œEarlier Than Ever, European Gas Storage Is Half-Emptyâ€ (Bloomberg). [h/t Rose Mintzer-Sweeney]

Â 

Whaling. WhalingHistory.org, a collaboration between the Mystic Seaport Museum and the New Bedford Whaling Museum, revolves around a series of interconnected databases. They include every known American whaling voyage between the 1700s and 1920s, entries from 1,381 of their logbooks, and some of their crew lists, plus records from British and French voyages. [h/t u/cavedave]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.01.19 edition
item.description: Political emails, foreign commerce interventions, commuting zones, tech support scams, and Wordle words.
item.content:encoded:
Political emails, foreign commerce interventions, commuting zones, tech support scams, and Wordle words.

Â 

More political emails. Derek Willis, a journalism lecturer with an expertise in political data, has published a searchable, downloadable database of 100,000+ email messages received in recent years by an address he created for this purpose, and â€œwhich I routinely plug into forms I find on candidate and committee sites.â€ The database, which Willis plans to update weekly, lists each messageâ€™s timestamp, sender, subject line, and body. Previously: The Princeton Corpus of Political Emails (DIP 2021.06.23), the Markupâ€™s collection of 5,000+ campaign emails (DIP 2020.03.04, and DCInboxâ€™s congressional e-newsletter collection (DIP 2021.03.03). [h/t jcberk]

Â 

Foreign commerce interventions. The Global Trade Alert, launched in 2009, â€œprovides timely information on state interventions taken since November 2008 that are likely to affect foreign commerce,â€ such as new subsidies, export quotas, import tariffs, or anti-dumping laws. Its downloadable dataset describes 33,000+ interventions, listing their types, implementing jurisdictions, affected jurisdictions, affected products, and more. The project, affiliated with the University of St. Gallen, has also started tracking interventions that affect digital commerce. [h/t Simon Evenett and Johannes Fritz]

Â 

Commuting zones. Decades ago, the USDA Economic Research Service developed a methodology to group the nationâ€™s counties into hundreds of â€œcommuting zones,â€ based on the Censusâ€™s journey to work data. Those groupings are available from the agency (for 1980, 1990, and 2000), and from researchers at Penn State (for those years plus 2010). More recently, Facebook/Meta has developed its own methodology for estimating commuting zones, using location data collected from its users. The projectâ€™s public dataset spans the world and specifies the zones not as sets of counties but as detailed, custom boundaries.

Â 

Tech support scams. From 2018 to 2021, the now-shuttered PopupDB Project collected information about tech support scams and their deceptive browser popups. Its maintainers have since released two final downloads: a â€œlightâ€ dataset that lists the URLs and web hosts of 11,000+ such popups, and a â€œfullâ€ database that includes screenshots and source code. [h/t NeeP]

Â 

Wordle words. You might have heard of Wordle. The gameâ€™s 2,315 possible answers and 12,972 permitted guesses are not an enormous secret, being embedded in its viewable source code. The Riddlerâ€™s Zach Wissner-Gross, for instance, has extracted those word lists into two spreadsheets.

Â

item.description: Slaveholders in Congress, pension plans, journal editors, radio on the internet, and chocolate bar reviews.
item.content:encoded:
Slaveholders in Congress, pension plans, journal editors, radio on the internet, and chocolate bar reviews.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Some updates: After nearly eight (very fulfilling) years as BuzzFeed Newsâ€™ data editor, Iâ€™m shifting roles there â€” Iâ€™ll be working part-time (for now) on a new initiative that Iâ€™m quite excited about. More details on that soonish. In the meantime, two related developments: âœ¨ weâ€™re hiring a new data editor âœ¨ (ask me about it!) and Iâ€™ve added a âœ¨ job board âœ¨ to Data Is Plural (see below).

Â 

Slaveholders in Congress. At least â€œ1,715 members of Congress were enslavers at some point in their adult lives,â€ according to a Washington Post investigation published Monday. Reporter Julie Zauzmer Weil began her research with a list of every person who ever served in the House or Senate, filtered it to those born before 1840, and then consulted their biographies, Census records, and other historical documents. The Postâ€™s public dataset, the first of its kind, lists the congressmen from that era, their dates of birth, positions held in Congress, states served, dates served, and whether the Post determined they were slaveholders. For 677 of the congressmen, the Post â€œcouldnâ€™t reach a conclusionâ€ and is seeking assistance from readers.

Â 

Pension plans. Public Plans Data, a collaboration led by Boston College professor Alicia H. Munnell, gathers extensive information about the retirement plans that state and local governments offer their employees, drawn from those plansâ€™ annual financial reports. The project maintains a range of datasets, including two decades of participation and financial figures for 200+ plans that account for â€œ95 percent of public pension membership and assets nationwide,â€ their investments, early payout options, and more. It also provides interactive tools and an API.

Â 

Journal editors. For his Open Editors project, Andreas Nishikawa-Pacher scrapes the websites of scholarly journals, extracting the names, affiliations, and roles of their listed editors and board members. The projectâ€™s dataset contains half a million associations between editors and 6,000+ scholarly journals from 22 publishers (17 mainstream and 5 â€œpredatoryâ€). Read more: Nishikawa-Pacher et al.â€™s introductory working paper. And: â€œWhy researchers created a database of half a million journal editorsâ€ (Nature Index, 2021).

Â 

Radio on the internet. Radio-browser.info is â€œa community driven effort (like wikipedia) with the aim of collecting as many internet radio and TV stations as possible.â€ The 29,000+ stations span 200+ countries and 280+ languages. You can explore them on a map, through an API, and via bulk database snapshots. [h/t jlkuester7]

Â 

Chocolate bar reviews. The Manhattan Chocolate Societyâ€™s Brady Brelinski has reviewed 2,500+ bars of craft chocolate since 2006, and compiles his findings into a copy-paste-able table that lists each barâ€™s manufacturer, bean origin, percent cocoa, ingredients, review notes, and numerical rating. Related: Craft chocolate makers in the US and Canada, also compiled by Brelinski. [h/t Andrew MaranhÃ£o]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2022.01.05 edition
item.description: Civil asset forfeiture, joint military exercises, medical drug names, foundation shades, and honey bees.
item.content:encoded:
Civil asset forfeiture, joint military exercises, medical drug names, foundation shades, and honey bees.

Â 

Civil asset forfeiture. â€œMost states and the federal government have laws allowing police and prosecutors to seize and permanently keep Americansâ€™ cash, cars, homes and other property suspected of being involved in a crime â€” without regard to the ownersâ€™ guilt or innocence,â€ the nonprofit law firm Institute for Justice writes in its third edition of Policing for Profit, published in 2020. The report gathers and analyzes datasets on property seized in dozens of states through this practice of civil asset forfeiture, and on the spending of forfeiture funds. It also examines seizures from the federal Consolidated Asset Tracking System, detailed public extracts of which the Department of Justice updates quarterly. As seen in: â€œCops still take more stuff from people than burglars doâ€ (The Why Axis, 2021), and â€œStop and Seizeâ€ (Washington Post, 2014).

Â 

Joint military exercises. Jordan Bernhardtâ€™s Joint Military Exercises Dataset describes 5,000+ such operations undertaken between 1977 and 2016, drawn from historical news reports. The dataset lists each exerciseâ€™s name, location, when it began and ended, the countries that participated, activities involved, and more. Related: Brandon J. Kinneâ€™s Defense Cooperation Agreement Dataset, a â€œcomprehensive, human-coded datasetâ€ covering bilateral defense treaties between 1980 and 2010.

Â 

Medical drug names. To build their International Drug Dictionary, Mohammad A. Khaleel et al. collected trade names and ingredient names â€œfrom open access websites belonging to official drug regulatory agencies, official healthcare systems, or recognized scientific bodies from 44 countries around the world,â€ among other sources. Each of the 450,000+ entries maps a name to standardized ingredient information from the National Library of Medicineâ€™s RxNorm database.

Â 

Foundation shades. For â€œThe Naked Truth,â€ a Pudding article published last year with Ofunne Amaka, Amber Thomas scraped information about 6,800+ foundation shades from the websites of two major cosmetics retailers. The projectâ€™s datasets identify each productâ€™s name, description, URL, and the predominant RGB/HSL color value in its swatch image.

Â 

Honey bees. Since the 1980s, the US Department of Agriculture has conducted an annual Bee and Honey Inquiry Survey, which generates estimates of â€œthe number of colonies producing honey, yield per colony, honey production, average price, price by color class and value as well as honey stocks at the state and national levels.â€ Since 2016, it has also published annual reports that examine the gain and loss of colonies, including losses due to colony collapse disorder.

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.12.29 edition
item.description: Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic, religious congregations, COVID-era news layoffs, leadersâ€™ economic persuasions, and root traits.
item.content:encoded:
Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic, religious congregations, COVID-era news layoffs, leadersâ€™ economic persuasions, and root traits.

Â 

Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic. Martin Eiermann, Elizabeth Wrigley-Field, et al. have conducted an analysis of deaths before, during, and after the 1918 influenza pandemic, drawing on â€œdata from multiple sources, including digitized mortality records for 70 U.S. cities, linked census records that establish urban residency status across multiple censusesâ€ and newspaper accounts of non-pharmaceutical interventions. The teamâ€™s published files includes a dataset that, for each city-and-year, lists the mortality rate overall, for white vs. non-white residents, and due to flu/pneumonia; a range of demographic variables; the timing of certain interventions; and more.

Â 

Religious congregations. The Association of Religion Data Archives, founded in 1997, â€œstrives to democratize access to the best data on religion.â€ Among its resources are four waves of the National Congregations Study, a Duke Universityâ€“based survey that asks US religious establishments about their denominational affiliation, buildings of worship, congregants, staffing, educational offerings, and more. Representatives from 5,300+ Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Buddhist, Hindu, and other congregations participated in the latest wave, conducted in 2018â€“19. [h/t Patricia Homan and Amy Burdette + Kevin Lewis]

Â 

COVID-era news layoffs. â€œAt least 6,154 news organization workers, which includes both editorial and non-editorial staffers, were laid off beginning March 2020 through August 2021,â€ according to a new report from the Tow Centerâ€™s Gabby Miller. An interactive tracker provides a map and downloadable table of the layoffs and other cutbacks, listing each outletâ€™s name, medium, owner, and location; the cutbackâ€™s date, description, and category (layoffs, pay cuts, etc.); and source links. Related: The Washington Post Magazineâ€™s Lost Local News issue.

Â 

Leadersâ€™ economic persuasions. Political scientist Bastian Herreâ€™s new Global Leader Ideology dataset â€œprovides unprecedented coverage of chief executivesâ€™ [economic] ideologies across time and space,â€ classifying their approaches as leftist, centrist, rightist, or non-ideological in 182 countries, from 1945 to 2020. Read more: Herreâ€™s introductory paper and Twitter thread.

Â 

Root traits. Oak Ridge National Laboratoryâ€™s Fine-Root Ecology Database categorizes the root characteristics of 4,500+ plant species, as observed and published in scientific literature. The hundreds of types of traits relate to vessel density, root angles, lifespan, macronutrients, microbial symbionts, and more.

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.12.22 edition
item.description: Tobacco habits, working hours, COVID-19 in European prisons, California water wells, and toothbrushing.
item.content:encoded:
Tobacco habits, working hours, COVID-19 in European prisons, California water wells, and toothbrushing.

Â 

Tobacco habits. Every few years since 1992, the National Cancer Institute has sponsored the Tobacco Use Supplement to the Current Population Survey, administered by the US Census Bureau. In addition to extensive demographic information, the supplement asks about historical tobacco usage (â€œHave you smoked at least 100 cigarettes in your entire life?â€), preferences (â€œDo you usually smoke menthol or non-menthol cigarettes?â€), purchasing habits, e-cigarettes, and much more. Anonymized responses and documentation are available for all survey waves through 2018â€“19. Previously: The CDCâ€™s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (DIP 2016.09.14). [h/t Christian Gunadi et al. + Kevin Lewis]

Â 

Working hours. Political scientist Magnus Bergli Rasmussen has compiled data on the regulation of laborersâ€™ total work hours in nearly every country since 1789, available as a Stata file. For each year and territory, the dataset indicates whether such laws existed, the â€œnormalâ€ number of contractually-obligated weekly hours, the maximum number of hours allowed, and increases in pay for overtime. Read more: â€œThe Great Standardization: Working Hours Around the World,â€ in which Rasmussen describes the datasetâ€™s construction.

Â 

COVID-19 in European prisons. A collaboration coordinated by Deutsche Welle and the European Data Journalism Network has gathered data on the pandemicâ€™s impact on prisoners and prison staff in dozens of European countries, including the number of COVID-19 tests, cases, and deaths over time. The data also note the types of preventative measures and vaccine policies in place. Previously: US prison COVID-19 data from the Marshall Project and AP (DIP 2020.05.06) and the New York Times (DIP 2021.04.21). [h/t Lorenzo Ferrari]

Â 

California water wells. Domestic wells in the San Joaquin Valley â€œare drying up at an alarming paceâ€ amid â€œa frenzy of new well construction and heavy agricultural pumping,â€ according to a Los Angeles Times article last week. Data reporter Gabrielle LaMarr LeMeeâ€™s analysis provides the quantitative backbone, drawing on three state datasets: well completion reports and periodic groundwater level measurements, both of which go back more than a century, and household water supply shortage reports since 2013.

Â 

Toothbrushing. Zawar Hussain et al. recorded data from 120 electric and manual toothbrushing sessions, using sensors attached to the brush handle and brusherâ€™s wrist. Each sessionâ€™s data files trace the sensorsâ€™ positions over time and indicate the brush type, participantâ€™s gender, age, and handedness, and more.

Â
